columns.text: In this problem, we will try to interpret the given interpretation which uses the two-stage dividend growth approach.

However, we can recall that the the dividend after $t$ years can be solved using the combination of the growth rate at both stages. This can the be represented as:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{D}_{t+1}&=\text{D}_0(1+\text{g}_1)^t(1+\text{g}_2)
\end{aligned}$$

Where,

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{D}_0&=\text{Initial dividend}\\
\text{g}_1&=\text{Growth rate at first stage}\\
\text{g}_2&=\text{Growth rate at second stage}\\
\text{t}&=\text{Time}
\end{aligned}$$

Combining the expressions in Step 3 and Step 7, we will get the same expression that is seen on the book which is:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{P}_0&=\left[\text{D}_0(1+\text{g}_1)\times\dfrac{1-\left(\frac{1+\text{g}_1}{1+\text{R}}\right)^t}{\text{R}-\text{g}_1}\right]+\left[\dfrac{\text{D}_0(1+\text{g}_1)^t(1+\text{g}_2)}{\text{R}-\text{g}_2}\times\dfrac{1}{(1+\text{R})^t}\right]
\end{aligned}$$

The expression basically tells us that the current price of a company's share is given by the sum of the present value of its dividends up to time $t$ and the present value of the company's stock at time $t$.
